channel.title: Seeds of discontent
channel.description:
Documentary series addressing: race relations, civil rights, poverty, youth, crime, deliquency. Host: Hartford Smith, Jr., Supervisor of the Michigan Department of Social Services Screening and Intake Unit and Assistant Professor of Social Work at Wayne State University School of Social Work.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: Program 15 of 26
item.description: A continuation of Progam 14 (interviews with Negro professionals and middle class members: psychologist, newspaper editor, car salesman), plus some thoughts on future developments.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 20 of 26
item.description: Takes a look at the growing discontent and rebellion of college students across the nation. Presents interviews with student activists from the campus of Wayne state University who had been in serious conflict with "the establishment". In-depth exploration of causation and what is needed.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Program 13 of 26
item.description: Political and social attitudes of the Negro professional man.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Program 17 of 26
item.description: A continuation of program sixteen with an in-depth exploration of organizational and program defects as they apply to the educational needs of Negro children.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 22 of 26
item.description: An exploration of the growing sense of militancy and discontent among public school teachers. The cause is explored by means of interviews with a selected group of discontented teachers from the inner city schools of Detroit.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 19 of 26
item.description: The section of the series on the American Negro concludes by loooking at the future through the eyes of Negro children attending two predominantly black junior high schools bordering on the two largest housing projects in the city of Detroit.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 3 of 26
item.description: Poverty stricken citizens in the inner city of Detroit discuss problems of shelter, food, clothing and recreation; they discuss plight of the poor, their hopes and disappointments.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 12 of 26
item.description: Guests: Odetta, Dick Gregory, Leslie Grinage on what should be done in entertainment field.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 14 of 26
item.description: A continuation of interviews with Negro professional people and Negroes from the ranks of the middle class, with interviews with a leading Negro psychologist, Negro newspaper editor, and a Negro car salesman. The comments and reflections reveal growing awareness, concern, and very pointed calls for action on the part of the Negro middle class.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 16 of 26
item.description: A consideration of the American Negro and public education. This program reviews the role of education as a source of hope and frustration for Negroes. This sense of hope and frustration is considered against the backdrop of serious problems confronting present day school systems in large metropolitan areas. The program contains an interview with a Negro specialist in the field of program development in the Detroit school system.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 7 of 26
item.description: See also program #6. Older Negro men talk about Negro-police relationships, the riots, red-light districts, and the Negro community.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 2 of 26
item.description: Smith visits a "hippie pad" and explores communal living.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 18 of 26
item.description: This program deals with the emergence of black self-help groups in Negro ghettos. The program takes an in-depth look at current crises and needs in urban centers throughout the nation from the point of view of a leader of such a group in the Detroit area.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 8 of 26
item.description: See also program #6 and #7. Continuation of same discussions: Negro-police relationships, the riots, red-light districts, and the Negro community.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 23 of 26
item.description: This program marks the beginning of programs dealing with an assessment of the attitudes and reactions of established agencies and institutions as reflected by their programs in response to the unrest and discontent of the different forces in urban society. The response, the program, and the attitude of the United Community Services of Metropolitan Detroit, a confederation of one hundred health and welfare agencies with a budget in excess of $20,000,000, is examined; the program includes interviews with the managing director of u.c.s. and a union representative of employees of U.C.S affiliated agencies.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 25 of 26
item.description: An assessment of the response, attitude, and action by the Michigan State Legislature in the face of the growing crisis and the aftermath of the Detroit riots of 1967. The program includes an interview with a Senator from a predominantly black district of Detroit: the Senator presents some rather candid observations regarding the attitude and behavior of his colleagues in the face of the growing crisis.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 24 of 26
item.description: Assessment of the response, attitude and relevancy of Detroit's Poverty Program, including an interview with the director.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 4 of 26
item.description: As previous program (#3) but centering this time around medical care and effects of poverty on various ethnic groups such as poor Negroes and southern whites.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 5 of 26
item.description: Feelings and attitudes about contemporary welfare systems. See also programs #3 and #4.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: Welfare

item.title: Program 6 of 26
item.description: Historical perspective on problems of the Negro. A group of older Negro men, residents of Detroit upwards of 40 years, describe why the Negro left the South, what he was looking for and what he found in north.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 11 of 26
item.description: Problems of the Negro in general society are discussed by Odetta, Leslie Grinage and Dick Gregory.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.description: A continuation and conclusion of program twenty (campus unrest, student demonstrations, and the growing discontent and rebellion of college students.

item.title: Program 26 of 26
item.description: This entire program is devoted to Mr. Smith's observations, cornments, and conclusions regarding the nature and meaning of discontent in American society, what needs to be done, and what has to be done. Mr. Smith looks over the brink and answers the question, "what are the consequences for us all if there is no speed up in the solution of the social problems facing us?" He concludes with some pointed recommendations for future solutions.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Program 1 of 26
item.description: "The American Negro: The Historical Perspective." This program offers perspective on riots, rebellion, and the disenchantment of Negro citizens through the eyes of other Negro citizens who have lived in Detroit since the turn of the century. It stresses the continuity of this experience and history in the young as they relate to the living history experienced through their elders.
item.dc:creator: Wayne State University
item.dc:subject: Youth
